item.title: Sending automatic emails with R ğŸ“§
item.description: .blocks_style { font-weight: bold; background-color: whitesmoke; color: black; font-style: italic; font-family: Monospace; } Automatic reports through emails ğŸ“§ Impress your boss with automatic reports in their emails. Packages required: blastula: Package to send emails keyring: Set credentials of email ğŸ” Rmardown: Create automatic reports Read Rmarkdown file set directory of your Rmarkdown file tempreport <- file.path(...) Render mail with tempfile email <- blastula::render_email(input = tempreport) send email *credentials are explained at the end of the post!

item.title: Extract information with encoding in R ğŸ”¡
item.description: Are you a non English R user? In my case, Spanish language has the following letters: Ã¡, Ã©, Ã­, Ã³, Ãº, Ã¼ and Ã±. This letters are saved different depending on the encoding (computation language) of the table you are extracting the data. And reading them might cause some headaches. Tips ğŸ’¡ To avoid having strange characters when reading the previews letters, make sure you are extracting the data with the same encoding of the table from your database (check properties of the table) or excel file.
